title: JMeter Overview
description:
## JMeter Performance Testing Dashboard

This dashboard provides comprehensive monitoring for your JMeter load tests. Track request rates, response times, error rates, and JVM memory usage to ensure your applications perform well under stress.

**Statistics Configuration**
To match JMeter's calculation algorithms, configure `statisticsCalculationMode` in the plugin settings:
- **ddsketch** (default): Uses Datadog's [DDSketch algorithm](https://www.datadoghq.com/blog/engineering/computing-accurate-percentiles-with-ddsketch/). It computes approximate percentiles with a 1% error guarantee compared to the exact percentile value, while using very little memory. When compared with `aggregate_report`, results may differ more because `aggregate_report` picks the nearest observed value for each percentile, which can cause noticeable jumps when there are few samples.
- **aggregate_report**: Matches JMeter's "Aggregate Reports" listener. It stores all response times in memory and calculates percentiles using the "nearest rank" method (nearest exact value from the dataset).
- **dashboard**: Uses a sliding window and linear interpolation (by default) to calculate percentiles, matching JMeter's HTML Dashboards. This mode may diverge significantly from the others when the limit of the sliding window is reached (default 20,000, but [configurable](https://jmeter.apache.org/usermanual/properties_reference.html#reporting)).

See [configuration docs](https://github.com/DataDog/integrations-core/blob/master/jmeter/README.md#statistics-calculation-modes) to set the statistics calculation mode.

**Setup tips**
The plugin automatically adds a `test_run_id` tag to all metrics, logs, and events. Format: `{timestamp}-{hostname}-{random8chars}`. You can override this by providing your own `test_run_id` in `customTags`. In distributed mode, the hostname prefix becomes the `runner_id`.

**Support tips**
- Filter by `test_run_id` to isolate a single run.
- Make sure the time range matches the test run.
- In distributed tests, use the `runner_id` filter to compare results per runner.
- Logs widgets require `sendResultsAsLogs=true` and a valid Logs intake URL.

**Further reading:**
- [Datadog JMeter Plugin](https://github.com/DataDog/jmeter-datadog-backend-listener/)
- [Apache JMeter Documentation](https://jmeter.apache.org/usermanual/)
- [JMeter Best Practices](https://jmeter.apache.org/usermanual/best-practices.html)
- [JMeter Getting Started Guide](https://jmeter.apache.org/usermanual/get-started.html)
- [Datadog Log Management](https://docs.datadoghq.com/logs/)

definition.content:
## JMeter Performance Testing

This dashboard provides comprehensive monitoring for your JMeter load tests. Track request rates, response times, error rates, and JVM memory usage.

### Setup tips
The plugin automatically adds a `test_run_id` tag to all metrics, logs, and events. Format: `{timestamp}-{hostname}-{random8chars}`. Override by setting `test_run_id` in `customTags`. In distributed mode, the hostname becomes the `runner_id`.

### Statistics calculation mode
- **ddsketch** (default): Uses Datadog's [DDSketch algorithm](https://www.datadoghq.com/blog/engineering/computing-accurate-percentiles-with-ddsketch/). It computes approximate percentiles with a 1% error guarantee compared to the exact percentile value, while using very little memory. When compared with `aggregate_report`, results may differ more because `aggregate_report` picks the nearest observed value for each percentile, which can cause noticeable jumps when there are few samples.
- **aggregate_report**: Matches JMeter's "Aggregate Reports" listener. It stores all response times in memory and calculates percentiles using the "nearest rank" method (nearest exact value from the dataset).
- **dashboard**: Uses a sliding window and linear interpolation (by default) to calculate percentiles, matching JMeter's HTML Dashboards. This mode may diverge significantly from the others when the limit of the sliding window is reached (default 20,000, but [configurable](https://jmeter.apache.org/usermanual/properties_reference.html#reporting)).

See [configuration docs](https://github.com/DataDog/integrations-core/blob/master/jmeter/README.md#statistics-calculation-modes) to set the statistics calculation mode.

### More tips
- Align the dashboard time range with the test duration, or filter by `test_run_id` to isolate a single run.
- In distributed tests, compare percentiles per runner (use the `runner_id` filter).
- Logs widgets require `sendResultsAsLogs=true` and a valid Logs intake URL.

**Further reading:**
- [Datadog JMeter Plugin](https://github.com/DataDog/jmeter-datadog-backend-listener/)
- [Apache JMeter Docs](https://jmeter.apache.org/usermanual/)
- [JMeter Best Practices](https://jmeter.apache.org/usermanual/best-practices.html)
- [Getting Started](https://jmeter.apache.org/usermanual/get-started.html)
- [Datadog Logs](https://docs.datadoghq.com/logs/)
High-level overview of test execution including total requests, failures, and error rates.

Statistics summarizing the results of an entire test run.

### Not seeing results?
- Wait for the end of the test run, or disable the _final_result_ tag filter to see intermediate results.
- Make sure the time range covers the test run, or filter by `test_run_id` if you tag runs.
- In distributed tests, percentiles are per runner; use the `runner_id` filter to compare with JMeter.
- `runner_id` is only emitted in distributed mode. For local runs, use `runner_host` or `runner_mode:local` instead.

### Statistics calculation mode
- **ddsketch** (default): Uses Datadog's [DDSketch algorithm](https://www.datadoghq.com/blog/engineering/computing-accurate-percentiles-with-ddsketch/). It computes approximate percentiles with a 1% error guarantee compared to the exact percentile value, while using very little memory. When compared with `aggregate_report`, results may differ more because `aggregate_report` picks the nearest observed value for each percentile, which can cause noticeable jumps when there are few samples.
- **aggregate_report**: Matches JMeter's "Aggregate Reports" listener. It stores all response times in memory and calculates percentiles using the "nearest rank" method (nearest exact value from the dataset).
- **dashboard**: Uses a sliding window and linear interpolation (by default) to calculate percentiles, matching JMeter's HTML Dashboards. This mode may diverge significantly from the others when the limit of the sliding window is reached (default 20,000, but [configurable](https://jmeter.apache.org/usermanual/properties_reference.html#reporting)).

See [configuration docs](https://github.com/DataDog/integrations-core/blob/master/jmeter/README.md#statistics-calculation-modes) to set the statistics calculation mode.

# Latency

**Latency** is the time to first byte (TTFB) - from request sent until first response byte received.

Measures network + initial server processing.

# Response Time

**Response time** is total request duration - from request sent to complete response received.

Includes network, server processing, and body transfer.

Track JMeter assertion results to validate response content, status codes, and other test conditions. Failures mean the assertion evaluated and did not pass; errors mean the assertion could not be evaluated.

# Samples per second

Samples are tracked when **completed**, not when initiated. This means the count reflects finished requests including their full round-trip time.

**OK** = successful responses
**KO** = failed responses (errors, timeouts, assertion failures)

# Load & Bandwidth

**Active Threads** = concurrent virtual users executing samplers.

**Bytes** = network bandwidth (sent/received) per sampler.
Individual test results as logs. Filter by sampler, response code, or status.
